title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support conservation activities to protect Japanese loggerhead nesting population. Under this Award the Recipient will work with fisherman to reduce by-catch mortality with pound net fisheries in Japan and will host a special session at the 2010 World Small Scale Fisheries Congress to assemble current knowledge and develop coordinated strategies for assessing and mitigating sea turtle bycatch in small scale fisheries.

title.narrative: Strengthening consrevation of Yellow-cheeked crested gibbon and other endangered wildlife in the Southern Annamites Western Slopes landscape

description.narrative: This grant will: (a) identify key trade routes for wildlife, timber and other forest products flowing from Seima and the wider landscape in Vietnam towards Vietnamese markets; (b) identify key sites with remaining populations of yellow-cheeked crested gibbon and other endangered wildlife in the southern Annamites western slopes landscape in Vietnam; (c) create accurate, up-to-date land cover maps of the southern Annamites western slopes landscape; and (d) assess wildlife protection and crime prevention capacity in the southern Annamites western slopes landscape.....Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) produce, through GIS analysis, the first accurate map of land cover, land management units, transport infrastructure for areas adjacent to Seima Protected Forest and Snoul Wildlife Sanctuary; (2) carry out biological field surveys to identify key sites across the Southern Annamites Western Slopes landscape for Yellow-cheeked Gibbons and other key species (i.e. tiger prey, elephant, doucs); (3) assess enforcement capacity and effectiveness in Binh Phuoc and Dak Nong province including a training needs assessment, a review of inter-agency cooperation, a collation of provincial legislation on wildlife conservation/wildlife crimes, and a review of enforcement effort in key enforcement agencies; and (4) carry out interview surveys with local people and government staff to identify key trade routes for wildlife, timber and other forest products flowing from Cambodia into Vietnam.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This grant will improve direct protection of the last remaining population of this species in Vietnam by linking local livelihood improvement to the protection and presence of the species. This will be done by: (a) building capacity of Community-Based Monitoring Groups (CBMG) to improve protection of the Mu Cang Chai - Muong La forest complex ; (b) improving scientific knowledge on the Western Black Crested Gibbon population to provide guiding information on protection measures; and (c) introducing conservation education at schools in surrounding villages.....Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) recruit additional community members to increase the number of CBMGs; (2) equip all CBMGs appropriately, so that each team has at least a GPS unit, a camera, uniforms, shoes, backpacks, sleeping bags and hammocks; (3) train CBMGs in patrolling techniques and establish MIST as an approved patrolling..System; (4) conduct a study tour to Nam Et- Phou Louey; (5) encourage the development of a performance based award system; (6) develop a management and financing plan for the CBMGs; (7) train CBMGs in species monitoring; (8) conduct regular census surveys; (9) establish a database for key species and other wildlife records; (10) develop an educational unit for secondary schools on the subject of environment, wildlife and conservation; (11) develop educational materials to use in the unit; and (12) conduct training of teachers to implement the educational unit at all schools surrounding..Muong La Watershed Forest.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "This project will gather information about the illegal trade of rhino horn in Vietnam by engaging and training Vietnamese government law enforcement agencies and increasing awareness about the plight of rhinos and the harm done by the rhino horn trade in the local media. .Specific activities will include (1) a study of the illegal trade dynamics in Vietnam, specifically rhino horn consumption and domestic demand; (2) conduct two workshops for a total of 100 government officers from the judiciary, including court authorities, prosecutors office and peoples committees in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi, to.increase understanding of illegal rhino horn trade and relevant laws and treaties; (3) conduct one journalist training workshop in Hanoi for 25 local journalists to provide information on the international wildlife trade (specifically rhino horn), guidance on key issues and messaging; and (4) provide technical assistance and support to the CITES MA and other relevant national agencies on management of their rhino horn and elephant ivory stockpile.."

description.narrative: "In partnership with Fauna and Flora International, this project will support a conservation effort for the Tonkin snub-nosed monkey (Rhinopithecus avunculus) in northern Vietnam, by improving forest management and species protection. Specific activities include: (1) a forest management advisory committee to facilitate dialogue between stakeholders and to build support for conservation interventions; (2) community-based patrols to deter hunting of endangered species and other illegal activities; and (3) an awareness campaign to promote sustainable forest management among local villagers and school children, and to promote species conservation among the national television audience.."

title.narrative: Strengthening collaborative efforts to fight tiger and other illegal wildlife trade on the Vietnam-China border

description.narrative: This grant will strengthen collaborative efforts to fight tiger and other illegal wildlife trade on this border. The Recipient will do this by: (a) developing multi-agency monitoring systems for transnational wildlife crimes and law enforcement in a cross-border context; (b) strengthening capacity and building conservation support within frontline border enforcement officers; and (c) leveraging actions to prevent smuggling by informing and building support within national government agencies, regional associations and counterpart agencies addressing similar cross-border crimes (e.g. human trafficking, e-waste, drugs, anti-terrorism).

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Building political support and enforcement capacity towards eliminating the trade in..Yellow-cheeked Crested Gibbons and other endangered species in South Vietnam

description.narrative: This grant will build political will and institutional capacity for the successful implementation of enforcement campaigns aimed at eliminating the illegal trade in yellow-cheeked crested gibbons (Nomascus gabriellae) and other endangered species in Southern Vietnam. The Recipient will do this by: (a) increasing the capacity of the Ho Chi Minh City Forest Protection Department and Environmental Police in response, strategic enforcement operations and case investigations relating to the illegal wildlife trade; (b) improving methods and formalizing systems for the ongoing monitoring of illegal consumption of wildlife in retail establishments; (c) supporting the development of a local volunteer group Action for Wildlife Organization; and (d) building political will in the HCMC metropolitan area for wildlife crime enforcement operations, resulting prosecutions and placement of confiscated wildlife, through collaboration on a high-level political communication campaign.

title.narrative: Leveraging political support to fight tiger and other illegal wildlife trade on the Vietnam-China..border

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce the volume of illegal trade in tigers across the Vietnam-China border through increased Government of Vietnam action to fight illegal wildlife trade. This will be done by: (1) facilitating central and provincial level inter-agency communication and coordination on combating transnational wildlife crimes on the Vietnam-China border; (2) enhancing communications and coordination between relevant agencies in Guangxi (China) and Quang Ninh (Vietnam) province on combating transnational wildlife crimes along their shared border; (3) increasing the attention and response from government of Vietnam on inspection of shipments and related investigations at the Mong Cai border crossing by coordinating and partnering with organizations and agencies working on the other forms of crime in Vietnam; and (4) generating domestic and international media coverage that supports prevention and suppression of transnational wildlife crimes.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain the habitats of the yellow-cheeked crested gibbon within the Bu Gia Map National Park by changing local peoples attitudes regarding wildfire prevention and suppression. This will be done by: 1. continuing to improve the relationships between communities and forest rangers as a way to prevent wildfire in Bu Gia Map National Park; 2. training at least 50% of local people to effectively manage fire inside the parks forests; 3. training at least eighty percent of the households residing near the parks forests to understand the risk of wildfire and how to suppress fires; 4. regularly monitoring the most flammable sites in the park to prevent wildfire during the dry season; 5. and equipping the most flammable areas in the park with signboards to help local people prevent wildfires.

title.narrative: Strengthening conservation of yellow-cheeked crested gibbon and other endangered wildlife in..the Southern Annamites Western Slopes landscape of Vietnam and Cambodia

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to build the capacity to address illegal wildlife trade, particularly trade in gibbons in this landscape by (1) conducting detailed surveys into wildlife trade networks operating in the landscape; (2) building capacity and interest in frontline enforcement officers from the SAWS landscape in tackling wildlife crimes by presenting a five day training program for frontline enforcement officers to build their awareness, interest and capacity to address illegal wildlife trade in their work area; and (3) developing provincial and national communications on the biodiversity and threats to the SAWS landscape by co-hosting with the Southern Institute of Ecology a workshop to present information on the SAWS biodiversity and threats to provincial and national government departments, party officials and corporations This workshop will include key stakeholders Cambodian portion of the landscape..."

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Decreasing anthropogenic disturbance in the Cao Vit Gibbon Conservation Area

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to assure the survival of the last remaining population of Cao Vit gibbons by reducing anthropogenic disturbance within the Cao Vit Gibbon Conservation Area. This will be done by: 1) replacing 9 wooden water wheels with steel water wheels in the 3 communes around the CVGCA; 2) presenting a training course on the sustainable harvesting of fuel wood for the 3 communes around the protected area; 3) conducting a village training course on cultivation of elephant grass and providing seedlings and fertilizer to introduce the plant to all three communes around the protected area; 4) conducting a goat buy-back scheme; 5) erecting 10 new and repairing 10 old protected area boundary markers; 6) constructing livestock exclusion fences on the protected area boundary at the most commonly used access points; 7) repairing 3 existing gibbon information boards and erecting 3 new ones in local villages; and 8) producing and distributing to local communes 1000 calendars using photographs of the Cao Vit gibbon and project activities.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce the illegal trade of rhinos and tiger parts into, within and through Viet Nam, by providing Vietnamese wildlife law enforcement authorities with forensic identification techniques with which to prosecute and suppress wildlife crime. This will be done by (1) establishing wildlife forensic capacity at the laboratories of the Viet Nam CITES scientific authority; (2) transferring the latest DNA analysis techniques relating to rhino and tiger identification; (3) developing an individual DNA database of tigers in Viet Nam for subsequent trade control; (4) training enforcement officers in forensic evidence handling as part of wildlife crime investigations; and (5) developing the framework for wildlife forensic delivery within Viet Nam and the ASEAN region. These objectives will be achieved during the project lifetime through a combination of hands on laboratory training, forensic method implementation, enforcement workshops and dissemination.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to assess and strengthen the conservation of the yellow-cheeked crested gibbon on the southeastern slope of the Da Lat Plateau. This will be done by: (1) presenting a short training course to the staff of two protected areas and forest rangers of the state forest enterprises on primate classification, ecological and behavioral characteristics of gibbons, listening post survey and line transect survey techniques, and equipment use; (2) providing field experience at the end of the training and introducing a plan to survey specific sites; (3) conducting both listening post surveys and line transect surveys in all suitable habitats; (4) estimating the total population of the two provinces (Ninh Thuan and Khanh Hoa provinces) and identifying the important sites for continued conservation efforts; and (5) presenting a provincial workshop to inform government officials of results of the project and recommend incorporation of project results into conservation planning of the two provinces.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal titled Tackling consumer demand for tigers, rhinos and other endangered wildlife in Vietnam is to protect the countrys biodiversity..This will be done by: 1) producing two PSAs focused on wildlife consumers; 2) expanding ENVs distribution and airing of PSAs by formulating an agreement to air a series of PSAs on a regular basis with key provincial television stations; 3) producing 10 Voice of Vietnam radio shows which encourage reporting of wildlife crimes to local authorities or ENV; 4) carrying out a total of 10 public wildlife demand reduction events in public parks and forums in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City; 5) hosting at least eight university seminars on wildlife trade in Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi and Vinh City and thoroughly evaluating the seminar program and identifying ways to improve it and more effectively engage students; 6) obtaining agreements with 10 markets in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi and then hanging demand reduction banners over the markets for extended periods of up to six months; 7) continuing to operate a national toll free wildlife crime hotline to receive and responding to calls from the public reporting crimes; 8) continuing ongoing investigations of five major networks supplying rhino horn, tigers, pangolins, and ivory to Vietnamese, developing findings which profile these organizations, and sharing this information with trusted law enforcement agencies to support investigations and prosecutions of major figures within the networks; 9) establishing a mechanism for timely sharing of information with law enforcement both inside and outside of Vietnam; 10) producing a public annual report on wildlife crime and profiling consumer trade utilizing data from the consumer crime campaigns; 11) completing inspections of all nine tiger farms, photographing and creating identification profiles for all of the captive tigers and then provide training to the Forest Protection Department and Environmental Police

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino horn demand reduction in Viet Nam

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to engage university students, school children and the Vietnam Womens Association (VMU) in demand reduction campaigns in Ho Chi Minh, Da Nang, Hai Phong, Nha Trang and Can Tho. This would be done by: (1) delivering two-hour rhino conservation presentations to a minimum of 250 students at five universities in each municipality and accompanying those presentations with distribution of rhino conservation education materials; (2) inviting students to submit their rhino horn demand reduction campaign ideas to the CITES Management Authority of Viet Nam (CMAVN), having the CMA VN and HSI judge those ideas and award prizes and support for implementation of the best idea; (3) visiting (that is HSI and the CMA VN) at least five primary schools, reaching a minimum of 3,000 children, with their demand reduction campaign message in each municipality and distributing rhino conservation educational materials; (4) working with the teachers in the schools to have the parents complete a survey about the impact of the rhino school visits on people in each childs circle of family and friends; (5) inviting some of the teachers and students to participate in the second and third national stakeholder workshops in 2014 and 2015 respectively to explain what they learned about rhinos through the campaign; (6) holding rhino conservation awareness workshops with a minimum of fifty representatives from the local womens associations (VMU) in each municipality; (7) ensuring presentations to the VMU groups are accompanied by distribution of rhino conservation education materials; and (9) engaging the Viet Nam and international press at relevant times during this work in order to spread the campaign message as widely as possible.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Addressing the illegal trade and understanding the demand for rhino horn in Vietnam

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to strengthen the Vietnamese criminal justice system to more effectively prevent, detect and suppress Vietnamese citizens involved in illegal rhino horn trade, thereby reducing the threat of illegal trafficking to the survival of rhino species. This will be done by: 1) generating more detailed profiles on known traders, and new information on major rhino horn traders and their networks for law enforcement action; 2) catalyzing progress and providing technical support to ongoing investigations and prosecutions into open cases of rhino horn crimes by police and prosecutors; 3) increasing understanding and building consensus within local civil society groups, private and public sector key opinion leaders and the media on tackling illegal rhino horn trade in Vietnam; and 4) increasing local media coverage on illegal rhino horn trade issues and the wildlife crime suppression efforts of both Vietnam and enforcement agencies of other nations...Specifically this will be done by: (1) conducting surveys into illegal rhino horn trade networks; (2) carrying out a meeting for international and domestic LE agencies to review on-going rhino horn violation cases, and lend pressure to urge progress; (3) carrying out a roundtable meeting with Vietnamese prosecutors to review the current legal framework, (4) identifying loopholes and overcoming difficulties in processing illegal rhino horn trade related cases; (5) carrying out informal meetings for key opinion leaders, media, and local civil society to leverage support for rhino conservation and a strong anti-trade/consumption voice in Vietnam; (6) providing technical support to the CITES MA for report preparation and CoP16 decision implementation, including returning seized rhino horn or samples to South Africa for forensic analysis; (7) increasing local media coverage on illegal rhino horn trade issues by the distribution (and translation where necessary) of information through communication channels

title.narrative: Support for community based marine turtle nesting beach conservation and bycatch reduction in Vietnam

description.narrative: The recipient will implement community based nesting beach conservation programs and bycatch monitoring in Quang Ninh, Quang Tri, Quang Nam, Quang Ngai, Binh Dinh, and Binh Thuan provinces as well an education and outreach activities in 6 coastal communities involving about 300 fishers and 500 school children. Grantee will also assist Vn Governmental Institutions with updateing and implementing Marine Turtle Conservation Action Plan 2014-2012. The USFWS will work closely with grantee in setting goals, priorities, and developing budgets, and will provide assistance as needed and requested in engaging with National Governmental and other institutions to improve collaboration and conservation outcomes.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Addressing supply-side trade and habitat degradation to conserve the Critically endangered Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkey in Quan Ba, Vietnam

description.narrative: This project will reduce poaching and illegal habitat destruction of the Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkey (TSNM) by focusing on improving forest management by local authorities and communities. Specific activities include: (1) providing direct protection from hunting and trade of the resident population of the TSNM through a gun confiscation program, an assessment of wildlife traders and trade routes, and support of community-based patrolling in Quan Ba; (2) reducing anthropogenic pressure on the TSNM population and their habitat by identifying hotspots of habitat conversion through remote sensing, mapping the extent of Lysimachia and cardamom cultivation, and developing an action plan for reduced impact Lysimachia and cardamom cultivation.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to provide accurate information on the status of the gibbons of this region, encourage involvement of local people in gibbon monitoring and conservation, and facilitate establishment of new protected areas in the region. This will be done by: 1) establishing community-based monitoring and patrol teams; 2) providing training on gibbon survey techniques; 3) estimating the population size of gibbons and identifying key sites for conservation of gibbons and other endangered primates; 4) providing training on identification of globally threatened and most commonly traded species in the region; and 5) conducting an awareness raising program in secondary schools and villages in two districts.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Benefit sharing access and the conservation of the yellow-cheeked crested gibbons within Vietnams Bu Gia Map National Park

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to better protect the habitats of the yellow-cheeked crested gibbon within the Bu Gia Map National Park by limiting the impacts of local people on the core zone of the park and by increasing the incomes of these people by creating benefit sharing mechanisms within the park. This will be done by: 1) conducting focus groups involving local people to identify target species that are normally collected by local people as non-timber forest products; 2) creating a map of the areas that can be harvested without disturbing the gibbons or damaging their habitats; 3) conducting line transect surveys of the harvestable species; 4) preparing permanent plots for use in estimating the growth rates of target harvestable species within the selected areas so the park mangers can then determine the amount of non-timber forest products that can be harvested by the people to ensure sustainability; 5) formalizing agreements on access to park areas by local people for the purpose of benefit sharing; 6) creating non-timber forest management councils that will cooperate with park mangers to control and monitor local peoples activities within the park; and 7) using sign boards to create borders between the preferred habitats of the gibbons and harvestable areas.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Postal Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to disrupt and dismantle the networks trading yellow-cheeked crested gibbons and other endangered species in the Ho Chi Minh City Metropolitan Area. This will be done by: 1) strengthening enforcement on wildlife crimes in the Ho Chi Minh City Metropolitan Area (i.e. increased number of crimes/violations detected, people arrested and prosecuted, and increased revenue from fines); 2) strengthening regulation and management of private zoos and living collections of endangered wildlife in Vietnam; 3) generating intelligence and information for monitoring key wildlife networks, individuals and scale of their operation in the Ho Chi Minh City Metropolitan Area; and 4) strengthening capacity of frontline enforcement officers (forest protection department, police, border security and customs) in the detection and prevention of wildlife crimes...Specifically, this will be done by: 1) enhancing and upgrading the web-based www.giamdinhloai.vn platform to provide increased specimen identification, legal support and public reports to frontline enforcement officers; 2) collaborating with the CITES MA to develop plans on strengthening management and regulation of private zoos and living collections of wildlife in Vietnam (including hosting a meeting of local government agencies, zoos and collectors to develop suggestions for improvement of policies and regulations to be shared with relevant ministries); and 3) refining, focusing and formalizing successful survey methodologies on illegal consumption of wildlife to create a monitoring system for wildlife consumption and law enforcement..."

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to reduce anthropogenic resource extraction from the Muong La Watershed Area and Mu Cang Chai Species Habitat Conservation Area to halt habitat loss and stabilize the western black crested gibbon population..This will be done by strengthening community-based protection of the gibbons and their habitat; strengthening enforcement of the national firearm decree to curtail illegal hunting; and constructing a forest conservation station to allow more strategic patrolling. Specifically this project will include: 1) scaling up patrolling coverage by recruiting additional community members for the Muong La Community Conservation Teams; 2) providing equipment for Community Conservation Teams; 3) hosting SMART conservation software refresher training; 4) establishing a bimonthly SMART meeting to improve CCT patrol efficacy; 5) adapting the MAC (Management Advisory Committee) funding model from Mu Cang Chai to fund a MAC in Muong La; 6) hosting a firearm confiscation drive as called for in the Muong La Species Conservation Action Plan (village meetings and firearm confiscation drives will be funded in ten key villages); and 7) constructing a field station in Mu Cang Chai to enable strategic patrolling from the core zone of the Species Habitat Conservation Area. ."

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to initiate gibbon monitoring in the park carried out by local community members, produce a coherent gibbon management plan for the park; and involve local community members in the parks gibbon conservation activities to strengthen their commitment to conservation and the park. This will be done by: 1) presenting a week long workshop to teach the methods and techniques of monitoring; 2) selecting two-four person gibbon monitoring teams and carrying out gibbon monitoring within the park; and 3) holding a second workshop to discuss the threats to the parks gibbon population, the best methods to protect the gibbon populations of the park, and the best methods to educate the public living around the park on the laws and regulations governing the use of the park. This workshop is intended to lead to development of a gibbon management plan.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: First Meeting of the Pangolin Range States

description.narrative: This grant provides funding for the Humane Society of the United States / Humane Society International (HSUS/HSI) to plan, organize, and manage a workshop in collaboration with the Government of Vietnam in order to facilitate international cooperation on pangolin conservation. This workshop will provide a venue for pangolin range countries and governmental wildlife and enforcement agencies, non-governmental organizations and pangolin experts to present and discuss the latest pangolin population and international trade information in order to respond to CITES-prescribed calls for information and action. In addition, the workshop will provide an opportunity for participants to develop a unified action plan to protect pangolin species against over-exploitation as a result of international trade. The Government of Vietnam has offered to collaborate on organization of the workshop, and therefore the workshop will be held in Vietnam. Participation of the Asian and African Range countries and species experts is critically needed to meet the workshop objectives to ensure international cooperation from all stakeholders working for pangolin conservation. This project will be conducted as described in the HSUS/HSI grant proposal. The project consists of a series of activities that will occur over the course of approximately 3.5 months and that can be divided into three periods: pre-meeting, during the meeting, and post-meeting..Pre-meeting: During the nine-week period before the meeting HSUS/HSI will: facilitate regular meetings between the governments of Viet Nam and the United States of America, act as a liaison between the two countries on all matters related to the workshop, prepare materials for consideration and approval by both governments, launch and maintain an online registration site for participants, arrange for French and Vietnamese translation of relevant materials, receive and evaluate information and materials from the conference organizing company appointed

title.narrative: First Meeting of the Pangolin Range States

description.narrative: This grant provides funding for the Humane Society of the United States / Humane Society International (HSUS/HSI) to plan, organize, and manage a workshop in collaboration with the Government of Vietnam in order to facilitate international cooperation on pangolin conservation. This workshop will provide a venue for pangolin range countries and governmental wildlife and enforcement agencies, non-governmental organizations and pangolin experts to present and discuss the latest pangolin population and international trade information in order to respond to CITES-prescribed calls for information and action. In addition, the workshop will provide an opportunity for participants to develop a unified action plan to protect pangolin species against over-exploitation as a result of international trade. The Government of Vietnam has offered to collaborate on organization of the workshop, and therefore the workshop will be held in Vietnam. Participation of the Asian and African Range countries and species experts is critically needed to meet the workshop objectives to ensure international cooperation from all stakeholders working for pangolin conservation. title.narrative: Building on progress in tackling the illegal trade of endangered wildlife in Vietnam

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to, (1) Reduce demand for wildlife and wildlife products with a focus on high priority species including tigers, rhinos (horn), elephants (ivory), marine turtles, and pangolins; (2) Mobilize public action in efforts to stop wildlife crime and reduce consumption of wildlife; (3) Reduce consumer crime in major urban centers of Vietnam by expanding crime reduction campaigns which include reporting crimes to district level Peoples Committees and providing these committees a period of 60-90 days to address violations leading to a report card for each district, followed up by progress check on violators, etc.; (4) Disrupt and disable criminal networks engaged in the smuggling and trade of wildlife, by updating profiles on major criminal networks; (5) Strengthen wildlife protection policy and legislation; and (6) Strengthen ENVs role as representatives and the voice of civil society in Vietnam, by participating in CITES Cop17 focusing on rhino horn, tiger, and pangolin trade issues, and exchanging information with South African law enforcement.

title.narrative: Training on new penal code to improve enforcement of wildlife laws in Vietnam

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is two-fold: to counter wildlife trafficking in Vietnam by training enforcement officers to improve the enforcement of Vietnams revised Penal code on wildlife trafficking, thus reducing the number of animals removed from the wild and increasing risk for wildlife criminals; and to identify urgent priority needs for enforcement capacity building, which can serve as the basis of future work. This project is intended to conserve the wildlife trafficked in Vietnam, both endemic species and their products and those that are smuggled in and out of the country, by addressing the impacts of wildlife trafficking through heightened enforcement by relevant law enforcement agencies. Species affected by wildlife trafficking in Vietnam include rhinos, elephants,.pangolins, tigers, bears, leopards, turtles and other reptiles. Specific activities include: (1) implementing Vietnamese expert-led trainings to 300 wildlife enforcement officials whose posts are located in previously identified key wildlife trafficking hotspots throughout the country, which will provide basic.enforcement training as well as address changes in procedures resulting from the new Penal code; and (2) providing an opportunity to collect data on urgent priority needs of enforcement officials (such as equipment and training) that will enable them to do their work in general and in light of the new Penal code and other factors."

title.narrative: Strengthening the Foundations for Long-term Conservation of the Critically Endangered Western Black Crested Gibbon (Nomascus concolor) in Vietnam

description.narrative: The western black crested gibbon, Nomascus concolor, once common in southern China, northern Vietnam and Eastern Laos, is now Critically Endangered. It has been reduced to a few patches of primary forests, mostly due to tremendous deforestation, illegal hunting and wildlife trade, and weak law enforcement. In Vietnam, the contiguous forest block of Mu Cang Chai Species Habitat Conservation Area (MCC SHCA) and the Muong La Nature Reserve (ML NR) represent the countrys last viable population. The latest assessment was in 2014, when there were at least 19 groups around 80 gibbons (of a global population of fewer than 1,400). FFI discovered this population of N. concolor in 1999, with support from USFWS Great Ape Conservation Fund. The specific project objectives are: (1) Secure and scale up, and possibly operationalize, the model of Payment for Environmental Services finance for community-based conservation across this forest complex; (2) Maintain/improve community-based forest protection and monitoring activities; and, (3) Develop a coordinated, holistic and sustainable roadmap for long-term gibbon conservation through a highly participatory and pragmatic Species Action Plan.

title.narrative: Securing a stronghold and recovering populations of Sunda Pangolins in Pu Mat National Park, Vietnam

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to recover the populations of both Sunda and Chinese pangolins in Pu Mat National Park located along the Laos/Vietnam border in Central Vietnam by establishing a safe and secure stronghold for the species. Specific activities include: (1) build up a strong-hold for pangolins by building capacity for forest rangers and the border army to combat illegal hunting, trading and implementing a training program for both rangers and the military who patrol the border zone where poaching and cross-border trade is known to occur; (2) work with the Dan Lai community who live within and near the national park to raise awareness on wildlife conservation and the sustainable use of natural resources to reduce threats to wildlife; and (3) recover the population of Sunda pangolins by reintroducing rescued pangolins from the illegal trade and to monitor the populations by radio-tracking and camera trapping and establishing a field research project within the park to gather data on species ecology. It will also help build research capacity for rangers and the park scientific department with regards to equipment use, methods and data analysis.

title.narrative: Tackling the illegal trade of tigers, rhinos and other endangered species of willdife in Vietnam

description.narrative: This is funding year 1 of a 1-year grant. Education for Nature-Vietnam (ENV) is a leading conservation organization in Vietnam, actively and strategically working with government agencies, the general public, and other conservation partner organizations to stop illegal hunting and illegal wildlife trade in Vietnam. The purpose of this project is to continue to strengthen enforcement, improve and reshape policies and laws, and mobilize public support to combat wildlife trafficking in Vietnam. The project has the following objectives: (1) Strengthen policy and laws to help protect tigers, rhinos and other endangered species; (2) Combat illegal tiger trade and disrupt criminal networks engaged in smuggling and trade of tigers, rhinos, and other endangered wildlife; and, (3) Reduce consumer demand for wildlife and wildlife product with a focus on high priority species including tigers, rhinos (horn), and pangolins, and mobilize public action in efforts to stop wildlife crime and reduce consumption of wildlife.

title.narrative: Saving Vietnams largest remaining wild Asian elephant population

description.narrative: Vietnams wild Asian elephant population has been in steep decline for decades, with a total remaining population of approximately 100 individuals divided across multiple small populations and several provinces. The largest of these populations is located in Dak Lak province, where 60-65 animals remain centered in Yok Don National Park (YDNP), an area of dry deciduous dipterocarp forest. This two-year project continues previous work in the landscape, project objectives include: 1) conduct baseline research on elephant populations to enable strategic conservation and management interventions; and 2) reduce human-elephant conflict (HEC) to minimize impacts on local communities livelihoods and avoid retaliatory killings. Specific project activities include: 1) fecal-DNA assessments of to determine elephant population estimates through capture-mark-recapture approaches and population viability assessed through bottleneck analysis; 2) a feasibility study for GPS-collaring wild elephants; 3) develop an HEC management strategy in consultation with stakeholders; and 4) develop local stakeholder capacity to address HEC. This project will contribute to the conservation of YDNP, the largest protected area in Vietnam, and the remaining Asian elephants surviving in the landscape.

title.narrative: Enhancing Wildlife Trade Enforcement in Vietnam: Providing Technical Support and Training for.Implementing Government Agencies in Vietnam

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to undertake critically needed activities to enhance law enforcement efforts in Vietnam, where wildlife trade has been escalating over the last few decades, adversely affecting biodiversity in the country and around the world. Specific activities will include: (1)assessing technical need in enforcement agencies; (2) standardizing wildlife forensic protocols (in agreement with other Scientific Institutions) to support more effective detect, investigation, prosecution and deterrence of wildlife crimes; (3) facilitating the use of new technologies, i.e., DNA testing to support wildlife crime investigation and prosecution, especially for international wildlife trade case; (4) developing protocols for collaboration and information sharing between law enforcement agencies and scientific authorities; and (5) organizing training courses on standardizing wildlife specimen collection for ID and forensic test and evidence handling for law enforcement bodies and other skills needed to improve the effectiveness of their efforts in combatting wildlife trafficking.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Critically Endangered eastern black crested (Cao Vit) gibbon at Trung Khanh, North Vietnam

description.narrative: The project will accomplish the following objectives to help conserve endangered Cao Vit gibbons: (1) Minimize human impacts on Cao Vit gibbon habitat through community engagement and empowerment, with 50% of local community members expected to be engaged with Cao Vit gibbon habitat conservation by the end of the project period; (2) Enhance law enforcement capacity of protected area, with 100% of protected area managers and Community Conservation Team members having improved knowledge with which to address illegal activities in Cao Vit gibbon habitat; and, (3) By the end of the project period the current and potential habitat of the Cao Vit gibbon is known, mapped, and capacity is in place to maintain data for future use.

description.narrative: The purpose of this award is to support regional capacity building and inter-governmental coordination and cooperation of marine turtle conservation efforts in Southeast Asia and Indian Ocean. The intent of this grant is to provide travel support to increase participation of member countries less able financially to participate. Activities include: (1) a Conference of the Signatory Parties for the Indian Ocean Southeast Asia Marine Turtle MOU will be held in the Fall of 2018 hosted by the government of Vietnam to discuss an agenda of conservation issues such as trafficking of sea turtle products, a protected areas network, fisheries bycatch, and status of conservation efforts with the region. There are 45 member countires in the IOSEA including the U.S.

title.narrative: Strengthening the conservation of critically endangered gibbon Nomascus leucogenys in Vietnam

description.narrative: The critically endangered white-cheeked crested gibbon (Nomascus leucogenys) is one of the least know gibbon taxa in the world. Recent primate survey confirmed that the most viable population of this species in Vietnam is only found in the forest complex of Xuan Lien Nature Reserve and Pu Hoat Nature Reserve located in the west Conner of Thanh Hoa and Nghe an Provinces. Illegal hunting of gibbon still exists in the area as there is no gibbon and wildlife monitoring and education effort and there is no coordination between the two reserves in protecting the gibbon and other threatened wildlife. This project will: (1) Improve the conservation capacity for staff of Pu Hoat-Xuan Lien in gibbon and endangered wildlife conservation monitoring and conservation; (2) Establish and maintain a long-term gibbon monitoring program in the reserves; (3) Establish and maintain a gibbon and wildlife conservation education program to reduce demand on wildlife and mitigate threats; and, (4) Improve and maintain cooperation and coordination between the two nature reserves in protecting gibbon and other endangered wildlife, and regular sharing conservation experiences.

title.narrative: SECURING A STRONGHOLD FOR WILDLIFE IN VIETNAM AND RECOVERING POPULATIONS OF PANGOLINS IN PU MAT NATIONAL PARK, VIETNAM

description.narrative: Vietnam is home to Sunda pangolins (Manis javanica) and Chinese pangolins (Manis pentadactyla), but illegal killing for the international demand for pangolin scales and meat is having a devastating impact on their wild populations. Previous USFWS support to Save Vietnams Wildlife (2017-2019) helped to counter pangolin trafficking and bolster the population of pangolins in Vietnam by reintroducing rescued pangolins from the illegal trade, monitoring the populations through radio-tracking and camera trapping, and establishing a field presence within Pu Mat National Park to monitor the reintroduced pangolins. This project will address illegal killing and trafficking of pangolins in Vietnam by further securing Pu Mat National Park as a stronghold for pangolins and other wildlife. Specific activities of this two-year grant include: (1) recruitment, training, and deployment of 8 new anti-poaching staff; (2) collection and analysis of data on threats and illegal activities around Pu Mat in order to reduce illegal activities within the park and improve government action; (3) support for workshops and training of relevant stakeholders, including the Department of Agricultural and Rural Development, Forest Protection Department, enforcement officials, and rangers; and, (4) continued monitoring of released pangolins using innovative technologies such as camera traps and drones.

title.narrative: COMBATING THE ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRADE IN TORTOISES AND FRESHWATER TURTLES IN VIETNAM

description.narrative: Freshwater turtles and tortoises (TFTs) are highly traded, contributing to serious declines: of the 356 species of TFTs and marine turtles recognized globally, 61% are threatened with extinction. Despite establishing legal protections for 30 native species of turtles, TFT trafficking in Vietnam remains a serious threat to the survival of these species. The purpose of this project is to improve the protection of highly threatened TFT species in Vietnam through increasing the effectiveness in identifying origins and legal status of individual animals. Specific activities of this two-year grant include: (1) undertaking a needs assessment and review of illegal TFT confiscations in Vietnam; (2) developing clear guidelines on rescue of confiscated animals, placement and release options for native and non-native TFT species in the wildlife trade in Vietnam; (3) improving enforcement capacity of wildlife protection agencies in Vietnam through training and resource development; (4) augmenting the DNA database of endangered turtles in Vietnam with good locality data; (5) developing a protocol (using DNA barcoding) to identify turtles in the illegal trade and their geographic origins to aid in enforcement, monitoring of farms, and releases of confiscated animals.

title.narrative: TAKING ACTION TO COMBAT THE ILLEGAL TRADE AND EXPLOITATION OF MARINE TURTLES IN VIETNAM, PHASE II

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to implement a community-based sea turtle conservation project between.the mouths of the Karaslaya and Indio/San Juan rivers, an area which hosts the most important hawksbill.nesting in Caribbean Nicaragua. The intent of this project is to protect nests and nesting turtles from.poaching. Activities include: (1) training local community members to conduct twice-weekly surveys.from May through October along 36 km of the El Cocal nesting beach to count nests and deter poaching:.(2) conducting an eight-day field and classroom-based sea turtle course for four students and a faculty.member from Blue Fields Indian and Caribbean University; and (3) conducting outreach, education, and.awareness activities with municipal and communal authorities and local communities. El Cocal is.relatively underdeveloped and remote, and may migrate inland as sea-level rises, becoming a possible.critical nesting refuge.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF PRIORITY TORTOISE AND FRESHWATER TURTLE SPECIES IN VIETNAM

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to help conserve seven of the worlds most critically endangered species, one of which is Swinhoes.softshell turtle. Activities include: (1) securing a breeding group for the Swinhoes softshell turtle with only three known living.animals, two in the wild and one in a zoo in China; (2) promoting conservation of the Indochinese box turtle in Pumat National.Park; (3) bolstering a population of Bourrets box turtle through reintroduction; (4) initiating steps to create an expanded protected.area for the southern Vietnamese box turtle; (5) working to reestablish a wild population of the endemic Vietnamese pond turtle;.(6) determining the distribution of Zhous box turtle in northern Vietnam, which is only known from one captive specimen (7).identifying nesting sites for the Asian giant softshell turtle in Sekong River Basin, Lao PDR
